Uzi:

You have pointed to a very important point which majority of the people fail to recognize and do something about and that is "economic efficiency". Pharma has the most inefficient manufacturing technologies. As a result the focus become "regulation centricity". In order to comply and produce quality drugs they have to rely on analysis of intermediate at many steps of active ingredient manufacture and their formulations. All of the inefficiency costs are passed on to the patients of mutually subsidized healthcare system. Only recently people have realized the high costs of drugs and have complained about them.

Unless "process centricity" is incorporated in pharma, it will stay inefficient. Adoption of "process centricity" has to come from within the pharma companies but in the current business model that would not happen. Focus is invent new drugs even if that will serve 100,000 patients charge exorbitant price, make money and move on. FDA or another body cannot bring efficiency.

If pharma's model was adopted by other industries, they would not exist in less than six months.

We fool ourselves as a nation with serious consequences. Economic efficiency in the pharmaceutical industry requires competition surrounded by adequate regulation, tight supervision, and well-defined, relevant and predictable punishment. Presently none of these general requirements is adequately met, and those involved know it. The rest of us feel it.

I believe that handwriting -cursive--is one of the most important technologies we have.  Because it tells us whenever we create those glorious connected letters (and by glorious -- I don't necessarily mean legible to everyone or elegant to anyone else) and our hand moves rapidly across the page each new word emerging from the one before  -- that another idea is emerging.  With cursive,  our body is teaching our mind and our mind is teaching our body that there is alway, always another idea.  Cursive teaches us that ideas and words flowing out of the human mind and body is  as natural to us as breathing.
They use Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) for the brain scans, so there is no radiation involved.  There would only be a health risk if the kid had a metal plate in their head.

I would be terrified to see handwriting not taught anymore. I can type well, and I type a lot, but I can really only do certain kinds of emotional and organizational writing by hand.

To not teach handwriting would be robbing a certain number of kids of that form of language processing and communication.

My best insights surface when I write by hand. It's almost as if the act of forming letters and words invite the heart and other groups of cells to participate, and the brain is sidelined, marveling at the notions appearing on the paper. A generation can't afford to lose this ability, this tool.

In this single paragraph, you have bolstered the study's findings rather than undermined them by illustrating the precise shortcoming identified for those reliant on keyboarding: "For adults, typing may be a fast and efficient alternative to longhand, but that very efficiency may diminish our ability to process new information."
How will anyone use writing at all if it isn't taught? We need to know how to write by hand and to keyboard. Anything that will improve students' ability to think is valuable,  not a waste of time.

The 2012 James study focuses on preliterate children and really doesn't have much to say about the value of teaching perfect Palmer Method handwriting to 3rd graders. The correlation in the University of Washington study is interesting because it suggests that perfect penmanship is actually requiring extra blood flow and energy (perhaps a waste of resources). Overall the evidence presented does not offer support for using up valuable school time on penmanship. We will continue to use writing for lecture notes and brainstorming but it has been years since we turned in reports in neatly written longhand. We use word processors. We do not need to teach penmanship.

Back in the 70's, while teaching third grade for 6 years, I developed a method for teaching cursive writing, which was a lot of fun for the children and myself. We started by drawing letters in the air - all together. Like physical exercises - except with one arm. (With no possibility of making a mistake either!) Only once they got the motion of each letter did we move to writing on paper. I began with the simplest letters like "e" and "l" and we all had fun looping them in the air. You can picture each letter with a whole class of children enjoying learning to write cursivein the air.

All the children learned to write beautifully. And my handwriting improved too!

Following that time I ended up studying clinical psychology. So this article is immensely fascinating to me on the neural level.

I think it would be a great shame for people to lose the ability to write. If I'm writing a poem, for example, I really need to write it down. Typing would never work for that type of thinking. At least not for me.

It strikes me that if handwriting in childhood helps children to learn more quickly, what about the elderly? Should I be writing more and typing less to preserve or enhance my cognitive abilities? Should I maybe try writing words or letters in the air? Or teach myself to write that way using my left hand too?

Lots of avenues for research and creative thinking - all from this one article!

So actually, cursive handwriting is the only way that I can do certain kinds of writing, the only way I can organize some of my most complex writing, the only way I can access certain kinds of emotional processing.

You're really ready to rob a lot of kids of those abilities. Not everyone does, clearly, but some people really do rely on handwriting to access their best thinking.

Certainly American educators (those who support cursive) are undeterred by the factual evidence that cursive is slower and less legible than a hybrid hand. (citations on request)
Likewise, I have encountered several American educators, media publicists, and even legislators (who introduced or support bills to mandate cursive in schools) who have misquoted or misrepresented research papers in order to make these papers appear to support cursive. Those who have responded to my inquiries (including documentation of the misrepresentations made) have stated that they regard as virtuous their own decision to do so, because — they say — they do not believe that cursive could survive without such actions taken.
This research will have little effect on American schools. American educators are rarely deterred by empirical evidence from promoting the latest educational fad.
Did you type this note without really thinking about what you were typing?
The number of people who have posted counterarguments to the data-based conclusions of these these studies is disturbing. Another instance of the anti-scientific left and right.
